Replies.Reply: Another well dressed, middle aged man, behind a large polished oak desk, listening intently.  This is Leo.  He is short but powerfully built, with the face of a man who has seen things.
Tracking in on Tom, sitting in bed, smoking, staring at the bureau.  The rippling street light plays over him from the window.  We hear a distant knocking.
Looking down at the newspaper an the counter, next to a steaming cup of coffee.  Tom's hand enters to put some change on the counter, leaves, and we hear his receding footsteps.
Leo faces us from behind his desk.
The hubbub of female voices evaporates as all turn to look at the male intruder.

Slouched in a chair, in the corner of the room, facing Tom, is Bernie Bernheim.  He is about thirty and wears his overcoat and hat and a good-natured smile.  He holds an apple in one hand and a paring knife in the other.  The long peel of the apple corkscrews down off the knife.
Facing the door, from behind Bluepoint and Verna.
On Tom.
On Tom.  In the background, Bluepoint is walking over to the door to the room to close it.
Wider, from the other side of the car, as the car pulls away.
A loose shot looking over Tom's shoulder as he knocks on an partment door.  Head credits continue.
The bedroom, as Tom swings his legs around and gets out of bed.
is slouched, half-sitting, against the wall of the alley.
A man sits facing us at the counter in the foreground.  His face is hidden by the newspaper he is reading.
Tending the downstairs bar as Tom stalks over.
Over black we hear the sound of running water.
Gasping for air as his head is pulled out from under a running faucet.
Sitting up in bed, smoking a cigarette, thinking.  The bedroom is dark.
He runs back to his apartment.
Looks forward.
He looks stupidly at Bluepoint.  He looks ahead.
Closing his eyes.
The foot comes off his neck.
Waiting in the darkness just outside is another man in a topcoat and fedora.  He is holding two tommy guns.
Stretched out an his bed, wearing a robe over his pyjamas, smoking a cigar, listening--but only to the phonograph.
Hitting the floor and rolling under the bed.
On his belly under the bed, facing the door, swinging a handgun in front of him.
Jaw clamped on his cigar, he starts firing.
Still firing.
Firing.
Rolling out from under the bed.
Firing, the gun jumping and bucking in his hands.
Still walking calmly up the street, the gun still bucking in his hands.  Bullets whistle by and claw up the pavement around him.
His robe whips back in the breeze.  He fires again and we hear the distant sound of shattering glass.  The car weaves, runs up off the road, hits a tree and bursts into flame.
The explosion echoes over the cut as we track up the hallway behind Tom and a tall cadaverous man with pre-
Tom sits behind the wheel of the parked car; we are an his profile.
Tom gazes forward, jaw set, eyes off the doings outside.
Bernie is still on the ground, sobbing, not responding to Frankie who prods him with his foot.
Still kneeling, in shock, staring wide-eyed at Tom.
Pulling Bernie as he runs.  Foreground trees flash by.  In the background we see Tom standing, his gun dangling at his side.
A hand swings through frame holding the barrel of a gun, smashing the butt into a surprised face.
A man with a distinctive shock of white hair--Dead Terry McGill.  He puts up his gun and starts running along the roof.
Starts running along the street to keep pace, firing up at the facing roof.
Siren wailing, up on two wheels, taking a speeding turn onto the street.
Running, he is pointing, and bellowing at the car:  Bert Leo's man!  Up there!
Cops with guns hang out every window.  They start firing.
Bert . . . Up there!  Leo's--
As--CRASH--a foot enters to kick it and the door in.
One corpse an the floor beside him, the other corpse in the doorway behind him.
Checking the open chamber of his gun.  He snaps it shut.
Looking towards Tic-Tac.
He hauls Tom to his feet and pushes him towards Tic-Tac.
He stops singing and turns to look.
Taking a handkerchief out of his breast pocket and bringing it to his face as he looks at something on the ground in front of him.
A beat-up panel in the building's entryway, listing tenants' names and apartments opposite a row of buttons.
We are looking at the ground-floor window from the street.
A beat.  From inside we hear a pair of trotting footsteps--
Tracking in an a youngish secretary in a severe dress, sitting behind a desk.
We are close on Tom as, in overcoat and hat, he emerges from his apartment and looks down at the keys in his hand.
As Tom starts to shrug out of his coat, Caspar is crossing towards him.
Night, but sometime later--it has stopped raining.  The branches groan in the wind.  As they sway, streetlight glitters off the leaves, still wet with rain..
As he starts slowly towards the staircase.
He looks up.
Still climbing, looking at the body.
As he reaches the top of the stairs and swings around to face along the landing.  We hear a chuckle, close by.  Wind is groaning through the hallway.
